channel.description: Recent content in Anthropology on Ed Hagen

item.title: The universal genetic program and the custom-built phenotype: implications for race and sex
item.description: p.caption { font-size: 0.7em; } Could the scientific effort to understand sea urchin development, which began more than a decade before Darwin published On the Origin of Species, help teach us how to think about the biology of race and sex in humans? Maybe. Figure 1: Sea urchin development. Blue color indicates distribution of mRNA transcripts of activinB, a key signaling protein. Figure from Sethi et al. 2009.
